hints_html:
One way of solving this problem is to simply plug \(t=2000\) into the given possibilities and check if you get the number of sunspots that were detected in the year 2000.

A more methodical method of approaching the problem is as follows:

We know that the minimum of the function is 0 and the maximum is 120, which means that we are looking for a trigonometric function of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 60 + 60\sin(f(t))\end{aligned}\]

or

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 60 + 60\cos(f(t))\end{aligned}\]

for some function \(\displaystyle f(t)\).

Then we use the fact that the period is 11 and that the maximum occurs for \(t=2000\):

  • The period of \(\sin(t)\) and \(\cos(t)\) is \(2\pi\). What factor is the argument multiplied by to get a period of 1? A period of 11?

  • \(\sin(t)\) has a maximum at \(t=\pi/2\) while \(\cos(t)\) has a maximum at \(t=0\). How can you shift the function left or right to shift the maximum to \(t=2000\)?
hints_latex:
One way of solving this problem is to simply plug $t=2000$ into the
given possibilities and check if you get the number of sunspots that
were detected in the year 2000.
hints_raw:
One way of solving this problem is to simply plug <math>t=2000</math> into the given possibilities and check if you get the number of sunspots that were detected in the year 2000.
A more methodical method of approaching the problem is as follows:


We know that the minimum of the function is 0 and the maximum is 120, which means that we are looking for a trigonometric function of the form 

:<math> \displaystyle 60 + 60\sin(f(t)) </math> 
or
:<math> \displaystyle 60 + 60\cos(f(t)) </math>

for some function <math> \displaystyle f(t) </math>.


Then we use the fact that the period is 11 and that the maximum occurs for <math>t=2000</math>:

* The period of <math>\sin(t)</math> and <math>\cos(t)</math> is <math>2\pi</math>. What factor is the argument multiplied by to get a period of 1? A period of 11?

* <math>\sin(t)</math> has a maximum at <math>t=\pi/2</math> while <math>\cos(t)</math> has a maximum at <math>t=0</math>. How can you shift the function left or right to shift the maximum to <math>t=2000</math>?
question: A 07
sols_html:
Substituting \(t = 2000\) into the given possibilities gives

(a) \(N = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = {\color{red} 180}\)

(b) \(N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000 ) \right) = {\color{red} 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{22000}{\pi}\right)}\)

(c) \(N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000) \right) = {\color{red} 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{22000}{\pi}\right)}\)

(d) \(N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000) \right) = 60 + 60\sin(0) = {\color{red} 60}\)

(e) \(N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) \right) = 60 + 60\cos(0) = {\color{OliveGreen} 120}\)

Therefore, the answer is \({\color{blue}\text{(E)}}\).

A more methodical method of approaching the problem is as follows:

We know that the minimum of the function is 0 and the maximum is 120, which means that we are looking for a trigonometric function of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 60 + 60\sin(f(t))\end{aligned}\]

or

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 60 + 60\cos(f(t))\end{aligned}\]

for some function \(\displaystyle f(t)\).

Since the period is 11 years, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(t) = \frac{2\pi}{11} \cdot g(t)\end{aligned}\]

for some other function \(\displaystyle g(t)\).

Lastly, we notice that a peak was detected in 2000. If we used the cosine function, we would have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(t) = t-2000\end{aligned}\]

since the peak of the cosine function is at 0 (up to integer multiples of \(2 \pi\)). If we used the sine function, we would have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(t) = \frac{2\pi}{11} \cdot g(t) + \frac{\pi}{2}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(t) = t-2000\end{aligned}\]

since the peak of the sine function occurs at \(\tfrac{\pi}{2}\) up to integer multiples of \(2 \pi\).

Thus, the possible answers are:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11} (t-2000) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\end{aligned}\]

or

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t-2000)\right)\end{aligned}\]

The latter is a possible choice in the question, and so the answer is \({\color{blue}\text{(E)}}\).
sols_raw:
Substituting <math>t = 2000</math> into the given possibilities gives

:(a) <math> N = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = {\color{red} 180}</math>

:(b) <math> N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000 ) \right) = {\color{red} 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{22000}{\pi}\right)} </math>

:(c) <math> N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000) \right) = {\color{red} 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{22000}{\pi}\right)} </math>

:(d) <math> N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000) \right) = 60 + 60\sin(0) = {\color{red} 60} </math>

:(e) <math> N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) \right) = 60 + 60\cos(0) = {\color{OliveGreen} 120} </math>

Therefore, the answer is <math>{\color{blue} \text{(E)}}</math>.
A more methodical method of approaching the problem is as follows:


We know that the minimum of the function is 0 and the maximum is 120, which means that we are looking for a trigonometric function of the form 

:<math> \displaystyle 60 + 60\sin(f(t)) </math> 
or
:<math> \displaystyle 60 + 60\cos(f(t)) </math>

for some function <math> \displaystyle f(t) </math>.


Since the period is 11 years, we see that

:<math> \displaystyle f(t) = \frac{2\pi}{11} \cdot g(t) </math>

for some other function <math> \displaystyle g(t) </math>.


Lastly, we notice that a peak was detected in 2000. If we used the cosine function, we would have 

:<math> \displaystyle g(t) = t-2000 </math>

since the peak of the cosine function is at 0 (up to integer multiples of <math> 2 \pi </math>). If we used the sine function, we would have

:<math> \displaystyle f(t) = \frac{2\pi}{11} \cdot g(t) + \frac{\pi}{2} </math> 
and
:<math> \displaystyle g(t) = t-2000 </math>

since the peak of the sine function occurs at <math> \tfrac{\pi}{2} </math> up to integer multiples of <math> 2 \pi </math>.


Thus, the possible answers are:

:<math> \displaystyle  N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11} (t-2000) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right) </math>
or
:<math> \displaystyle  N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t-2000)\right) </math>

The latter is a possible choice in the question, and so the answer is <math>{\color{blue} \text{(E)}}</math>.
statement_html:
The number of sunspots (solar storms on the sun) varies with a period of roughly 11 years reaching a high of 120 and a low of 0 sunspots detected. A peak of 120 sunspots was detected in the year 2000. Which of the following trigonometric functions could be used to approximate this cycle?

(a) \(N = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\)

(b) \(N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000 ) \right)\)

(c) \(N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000) \right)\)

(d) \(N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000) \right)\)

(e) \(N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) \right)\)

roughly 11 years reaching a high of 120 and a low of 0 sunspots
detected. A peak of 120 sunspots was detected in the year 2000. Which of
the following trigonometric functions could be used to approximate this
cycle?

(a)
$N = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$

(b) $N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000 ) \right)$

(c) $N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{11}{2\pi}(t + 2000) \right)$

(d) $N = 60 + 60\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000) \right)$

(e) $N = 60 + 60\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) \right)$

(a) <math>N = 60 + 120\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{11}(t - 2000 ) + \frac{\pi}{2}\right)</math>
